metadata.title: A water-soluble palladium-salen catalyst modified by pyridinium salt showing higher reactivity and recoverability for Heck coupling reaction
metadata.journal: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical

A water-soluble palladium-salen catalyst modified by pyridinium salt showing higher reactivity and recoverability for Heck coupling reaction Linghua Yuan Yun Xu Xingbang Hu ⁎ Guoqiang Yang Youting Wu ⁎ School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210093, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University Nanjing 210093 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel.: +86 2583 596665; fax: +86 2583 336599. Graphical abstract A novel and water-soluble palladium-salen catalyst modified by pyridinium salt was synthesized and characterized by NMR, HRMS, FT-IR, ICP, elemental analysis and UV–vis spectroscopy. The catalyst can efficiently catalyze the Heck reaction between aryl halides and olefins. The reaction using 0.5mol% catalyst can achieve 98.3% conversion with 99% selectivity. The catalytic activity of catalyst modified by pyridinium salt is higher than that of un-modified one. Furthermore, the catalyst can be easily separated from reaction system by water wash and subsequently recycled for six runs without significant loss of activity and selectivity. Keywords Water-soluble palladium-catalyst Ionic salt Heck coupling Recycle Ionic liquid 1 Introduction Carbon–carbon bond construction is the basis of synthesizing many important compounds. Catalysts containing transition metal represent the most useful tools to achieve cross-coupling reactions under mild conditions with high yields [1,2]. Palladium catalysts (Pd-catalysts) have been widely used in Heck reaction, Suzuki–Miyaura coupling, and Sonogashira reaction [3–13]. In particular, palladium-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions of aryl halides for the formation of new carbon–carbon bonds have wide application in organic synthesis. Homogeneous Pd-catalysts have been extensively studied in synthetic organic chemistry because of their higher catalytic activity and selectivity [1,2,14]. However, one drawback of this kind of reaction is the separation and recovering of the catalyst when the reaction is completed. Reusing Pd is crucial because it is quite expensive, especially for large industrial practice. Binding the active metal complexes to insoluble or water-soluble carriers is an attractive strategy allowing separation by filtration or extraction [1,4–9,15–33]. Supporting Pd-catalysts on ionic liquid (IL) or ionic salt is an effective method to recycle these expensive compounds [1,23–27,30]. A serious of palladium complexes have been supported on ionic salt, such as triethylammonium ion-tagged diphenylphosphine palladium complex [23], pyridyl-functionalized imidazolium-based Pd-catalyst [24], imidazolium salt-coordinated palladium complex [25], sodium 4-(N-benzylideneamino)-benzenesulfonate based Pd-catalyst [26], and ionic Porphyrin Pd-catalyst [27]. These supported Pd-catalysts are homogeneous in reaction and can be reused by water wash [23–27]. Not all IL or ionic salt supported Pd-catalysts are water-soluble. 1-glycyl-3-methyl imidazolium chloride-palladium (II) complex was found to be a heterogeneous catalyst for Heck reaction [30]. To reduce the amount of Pd consumed in the reaction, besides recycling it, improving the reactivity of Pd-catalyst is also a crucial method. Though IL or ionic salt modification has achieved great success on recycling Pd-catalyst [1,17–29,16,30], little research concerns how to achieve recoverability and higher reactivity by the same IL or ionic salt modification. To achieve this aim, efforts should be made to design new systems in which a cooperative effect between the carriers and the metal center is well established. Basing on theoretic calculations, we had reported a strategy to support homogeneous catalyst by IL or ionic salt, which can enhance the reactivity of a catalyst [34,35]. Following the previously theoretic results [34,35], the focus of this paper is to bring out a new palladium-salen catalyst modified by pyridinium salt. This catalyst is not only recyclable, but also show higher reactivity compared with the un-modified one. 2 Experimental and computational methods 2.1 Materials and methods The reagents and solvents were analytical grade and purchased from commercial sources. They were used without further purification unless otherwise indicated. The NMR spectra were detected by Bruker ARX 500NMR spectrometer, using d 6 -DMSO or CDCl3 as solvents with TMS as the internal standard. Elemental analysis was performed on an Elementar vario EL II. ESI-MS were obtained on a Finnigan LCQ mass spectrometer. FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker APEX-III spectrometer using KBr pellets in 400–4000cm−1 region. ICP were recorded on Optima 5300DV. The progress of reaction was monitored by GC5890C gas chromatograph fitted with a SE-30 column (50m, 0.025m diameters) and a hydrogen flame ionization detector. The ultraviolet–visible light (UV–vis) spectra were recorded on a UV-vis SPECORD 200 spectrophotometer. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of Pd-[Salen-Py][Br]2 The palladium-salen catalyst modified by pyridinium salt (Pd-[Salen-Py][Br]2) was prepared as described in Fig. 1a. The [Salen-Py][Br]2 was synthesized according to our previous procedure [36]. The Pd-[Salen-Py][Br]2 was prepared by mixing Pd(OAc)2 (0.1mol), [Salen-Py][Br]2 (0.1mol) and 50ml water in a round bottom flask. The bottom was put in a 130°C oil bath to evaporate the water. During this period, fresh water was added continuously to ensure that there was enough water for evaporating. This process was persisted until the pH of the evaporating steam being neutral. After filtered and dried in vacuum, brown solid Pd-[Salen-Py][Br]2 was obtained. Yield: 81.5%. 1H NMR (500MHz, d 6 -DMSO): δ ppm 9.15–9.16 (d, 4H, CHpyrid), 8.83–8.87 (t, 2H, CHpyrid), 8.33–8.35 (t, 4H, CHpyrid), 3.69 (t, 4H, CH2), 3.33 (s, 6H, H2O), 1.71 (s, 6H, CH3), 1.68 (s, 6H, CH3). 13C NMR (126MHz, d 6 -DMSO) δ ppm 174.52(NC), 160.63(O–C), 150.24(Cpyrid), 148.10(Cpyrid), 129.82(Cpyrid), 121.39(C–), 57.25(CH2), 23.96(CH3), 17.86(CH3). Elemental analysis, Calculation for C22H26Br2N4O2Pd.3H2O: C, 37.82; H, 4.58; N, 8.02. Found: C, 38.19; H, 4.84; N, 8.27. ICP, Calculated Pd:16.4, Found Pd: 16.2. HRMS (m/z): [M−2Br]2+ Calculation for [C22H26N4O2Pd]2+, 242.0546; found, 242.0537. ESI-MS, Calculation for [M−2Br]2+ m/z =242.06, Found m/z =242.17. FI-IR (cm−1): 3348, 3060, 2921, 1622, 1587, 1467, 1409, 1356, 1291, 1262, 1228, 1161, 1125, 1095, 1052, 1024, 964, 786, 743, 696, 649, 636, 592, 470. 2.2.2 Synthesis of Pd-Salen Un-modified Pd-Salen was prepared as described in Fig. 1b. Salen-1 (0.1mmol) was added to the Pd(OAc)2 (0.1mmol) in acetonitrile (100ml), and then the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 8h. The resulted mixture was filtered and washed with dichloroethane, and the obtained light yellow solid was dried in vacuum. 1H NMR (500MHz, CDCl3): δ ppm 4.90 (s, 2H, CH); 3.44–3.45 (t, 4H, CH2); 2.05 (s, 6H, CH3); 2.00 (s, 6H, CH3). 13C NMR (126MHz, CDCl3) δppm 177.81(NC), 161.74(O–C), 98.92(CH–), 55.83(CH2), 25.27(CH3), 20.54(CH3). Elemental analysis, Calculation for C12H18N2O2Pd: C, 43.85; H, 5.52; N, 8.52. Found: C, 43.57; H, 5.62; N, 8.50. 2.3 General procedures for the Heck reaction In a typical catalytic reaction, 25ml three-neck round bottom flask was charged with Pd-[Salen-Py][Br]2 (0.05mmol), aryl halide (10.0mmol), olefin (12.5mmol), NEt3(10.0mmol), and DMF (15ml). The reaction mixture was heated to desired temperature and stirred till completion of the reaction. The reaction was monitored using a gas chromatograph. After completion of the reaction, a white precipitate appeared after water (10ml) was added to the flask. The products were separated by simple filtration. The products were identified by GC–MS analyses. The purity of the product was determined by GC. 2.4 Recovery of the catalyst After the reaction was completed, the reaction mixture was cooled down to room temperature. Then, water was added and the organics was extracted with diethyl ether. The aqueous solution was separated from the organic layer. The mixture of the catalyst and the DMF was evaporated to dryness under reduced pressure. Subsequently, the catalyst was used without further purification. 2.5 Computational methods All the structures were fully optimized by the DFT based B3LYP method. 6-31G basis set was used for these atoms except Pd and Br. It was necessary to take the relativistic effect into consideration for the transition metal and heavy element [34,35]. Hence, LANL2DZ basis set was used for Pd and Br atoms. Geometric configuration optimization, energy calculation, frequency calculation, and zero-point energy correction were performed by using the same basis set. Three different spin state (singlet, triplet, and quintuplet) were taken into consideration. All calculations were performed with the Gaussian 03 suite of programs [37]. 3 Results and discussion The catalytic activities of Pd-[Salen-Py][Br]2 were examined in the Heck reaction. The coupling reaction of idodobenzene with styrene was used as a model system (Table 1 ). The amount of catalyst used in the reaction is an important issue for coupling-reaction based on Pd compound due to its high price, especially for large industrial practice [1,2]. A control experiment indicated that the coupling reaction did not occur in the absence of catalyst even after 10h (Table 1, entry 1). Using 0.1mol% Pd-[Salen-Py][Br]2, the desired products can be produced with a TOF value of 37.8 (Table 1, entry 2). Using 0.5mol% Pd-[Salen-Py][Br]2, the highest TOF can be obtained (Table 1, entry 3). The influence of reaction temperature, solvent, and additive were investigated (Table 1). The results demonstrated that the temperature plays a significant role in the reaction rate. TOF value significantly increased from 0.4 to 24.8 with only 1mol% catalyst when the temperature increased from 70°C to 100°C (Table 1, entries 4–7). The obtained catalyst exhibited excellent solubility in water, DMF, DMSO, and NMP, but slightly dissolved in p-xylene and acetonitrile. However, reaction gave satisfied conversion only when DMF, DMSO, or DMF+H2O was used as solvent (Table 1, entries 3 and 9–14). About the base used in this reaction system, liquid organic bases are better choice, such as Et3N and Bu3N (Table 1, entries 3 and 18). Inorganic bases with poor solubility are not recommended because of the low conversions (Table 1, entries 15 and 17). For all the reactions investigated here, the trans:cis stereoselectivities range from 6.7:1 to 15.1:1 (Table 1). Using K2CO3 as base gives the highest trans:cis selectivity, but the conversion is low in this case (Table 1, entry 15). In cases whose conversions are larger than 90%, the trans:cis stereoselectivities range from 6.7:1 to 10.5:1. These selectivities are close to the same reactions catalyzed by Pd(OAc)2 supported by IL (trans:cis=6.7) [38], PdCl2{MeSC6H4-2-(CH2PPh2)} (trans:cis=8.7) [39], palladium polyether phosphinite (trans:cis=11.5) [40], and cyclopalladated imine complexes (trans:cis=6.8–7.4) [41], but higher than these catalyzed by palladium/SBA-15 nanocomposites (trans:cis=5.3) [42] and Pd(OAc)2/1- (a-aminobenzyl)-2-naphthols (trans:cis=0.6) [43]. Though IL or ionic salt modification have been widely used to recover the homogeneous catalyst [1,17–29,16,30,44–59], little effort has been performed on how to achieve recoverability and higher reactivity by the same modification. Basing on theoretic researches [34,35], we proposed that a conjugated linkage between the ionic salt and catalytic active center should be beneficial to enhance the reactivity of the catalyst. Herein, the experimental results confirm this idea. A comparison between the ionic salt modified catalyst (Pd-[Salen-Py][Br]2) and the un-modified one (Pd-Salen) shows that this ionic modification remarkably enhance the catalytic activity of the Pd-Salen without losing any reaction selectivity (Fig. 2 ). In the first hour of reaction, the conversion with Pd-[Salen-Py][Br]2 reaches 95.1%, whereas that with Pd-Salen is only 3.6% under the same condition. Though prolonging the reaction time to 8h, the conversion with Pd-Salen is only 19.5%. To understand the origin of the higher activity of Pd-[Salen-Py][Br]2, theoretical calculations were performed for both Pd-Salen and Pd-[Salen-Py][Br]2 (Fig. 3 ). The ground state of these two catalysts are singlet. It was found that ionic salt modification shortens the Pd-O bond length by 0.011Å. As a result, the Pd in Pd-[Salen-Py][Br]2 becomes more postive. The most important is that, comparing with Pd-Salen, the ionic salt modification drastically lowers the energy level of the lowest-unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMO) by 1.56eV and reduces the gap between the LUMO and the highest-occupied molecular orbitals (HOMO) by 1.52eV, which will make it easier for electron transfer. The catalytic activity of Pd-[Salen-Py][Br]2 is also slightly higher than that of Pd(OAc)2 which is the most widely used catalyst for coupling reaction (Fig. 2) [1,2]. At the same time, Pd-[Salen-Py][Br]2 can be easily reused whereas Pd(OAc)2 can not. The reusability of the catalyst is a crucial issue especially when using expensive palladium. The ionic salt modified catalyst Pd-[Salen-Py][Br]2 can be easily separated from reaction system by simple extracted from diethyl ether/H2O system. The catalyst can be reused at least 6 times without significantly loss in catalytic activity and selectivity (Table 2 ). Because the conjugated linkage between the ionic salt and catalytic active center, the variation of the anion will influence the electron structure of metal center. The anion of the catalyst was changed by the reaction between Pd-[Salen-Py][Br]2 and AgX (X=NO3 −, BF4 −, CH3CO2 −, PF6 −) in situ. The UV–vis results of catalysts with different anions show that the anion has influence on the electron structure of metal center (Fig. 4 ). As a result, the reactivity of these catalysts change with the variation of the anion (Table 3 ). Br− and NO3 − were better choice for this target reaction. Because changing the anion is quite easy, the reactivity of these ionic salt modification catalysts are thus easily controllable. The reactivity of this new catalyst for a series of aryl halides and alkenes were investigated (Table 4 ). Iodobenzene, 4-iodotoluene reacted with styrene at 100°C to give satisfying conversion in 98.3 and 94.8% respectively (Table 4, entries 1 and 2). However, 4-iodoanisole gave a lower conversion of 44.7% (Table 4, entry 3). Bromobenzene and chlorobenzene gave almost no coupling products, which is in agreement with the use of Pd(OAc)2 under similar reaction conditions (Table 4, entries 4 and 5)[60]. For methyl acrylate, n-butylacrylate, and methyl methacrylate, the TOF values ranged from 7.4 to 41.7 (Table 4, entries 6–8). 4 Conclusions A novel and water-soluble palladium-salen catalyst modified by pyridinium salt have been synthesized through a simple method. This catalyst can efficiently catalyze the Heck reaction between aryl halides and olefins. The reactivity of catalyst modified by ionic salt is higher than that of un-modified one. The types of counteranion in ionic compounds could affect the catalytic activity of the catalysts. Furthermore, the catalyst can be easily separated from reaction system by water wash and subsequently recycled for six runs without significant loss of activity and selectivity. coredata.dc:description: A novel and water-soluble palladium-salen catalyst modified by pyridinium salt was synthesized and characterized by NMR, HRMS, FT-IR, ICP, elemental analysis and UV–vis spectroscopy. The catalyst can efficiently catalyze the Heck reaction between aryl halides and olefins. The reaction using 0.5mol% catalyst can achieve 98.3% conversion with 99% selectivity. The catalytic activity of catalyst modified by pyridinium salt is higher than that of un-modified one. Furthermore, the catalyst can be easily separated from reaction system by water wash and subsequently recycled for six runs without significant loss of activity and selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: A water-soluble palladium-salen catalyst modified by pyridinium salt showing higher reactivity and recoverability for Heck coupling reaction
